facts.text: The respondent Municipality's case was that the appellants chemical works discharged effluent in very large quantities containing calcium, sodium and other salts through Katcha Channels thereby corrupting potable water of the wells in the surrounding area so as to render it unfit for use and also prejudicially affecting the fertility of the soil in the surrounding area by percolation.

The respondent Municipality, after obtaining approval of the Government, issued a notice dated 14th June 1956 to the appellant under s.153A(1) of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 (as adapted and applied to Saurashtra and amended), to show cause within one month why it should not be directed to arrange within nine months for discharge of effluent through covered pucca drainage and pumping it over 8 miles to Ran area of Cutch near Kuda.

Appellant replied by letter dated 10th July 1956: effluent discharged until 1943 through Katcha channel parallel to railway to Halvad; in 1944 new channel constructed away from Harijanvas, Kolivas and city; periodical surveys/tests by appellant showed no pollution; papers available for inspection; enquired if Municipality conducted tests; denied soil fertility affected; direction would cost 8-9 lakhs, cripple activities; scheme impracticable technically; objected and expressed inability to comply.

Respondent Municipality requested Government to appoint Special Officer under s.153A(3); Government by order dated 17th May 1958 appointed Mr. T.U. Mehta, District and Sessions Judge, as Special Officer to hold enquiry within three months.

Special Officer framed 7 issues: Issues 1-4 preliminary; Issue 4: whether discharge polluting water/soil is subjective satisfaction of Municipality beyond enquiry scope; Issue 6: if Issue 4 negative, proved effluents corrupt water/unfit and affect soil; Issue 5: notice mala fide/arbitrary; Issue 1: ss.153A-153G violate Arts 14,19,31; decided Issue 4 affirmative, Issue 6 not arise; Issue 5 out of purview; Issue 1 rejected re Art 19; Issues 2-3 for appellant; ordered proceed to Issue 7 only (recommendation on method/manner if nuisance found).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Special Officer erred in holding that the question of whether discharge of effluent pollutes water and affects soil fertility is for subjective satisfaction of Municipality and beyond scope of enquiry (Issues 4 and 6).
Whether ss.153A to 153G of the Act violate fundamental rights under Articles 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution (Issue 1).
Whether the notice was mala fide, arbitrary, capricious and without sufficient application of mind (Issue 5).

petitioner_arguments.text: Special Officer unduly restricted scope of enquiry by erroneous view, refused to exercise jurisdiction under Act; must enquire into existence of nuisance when absolute objection to notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.153A(3) of Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901

petitioner_arguments.text: s.153A of the Act offends Art. 19 of the Constitution.

respondent_arguments.text: Special Officer did not err; existence of nuisance under s.153A(1) is subjective satisfaction of Municipality, beyond enquiry; enquiry only on requisition/manner of discharge.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.153A(1), (3) of Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901

respondent_arguments.text: s.153A does not offend Art. 19 as reasonable restriction to prevent nuisance affecting public health and soil fertility.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.153A(1), issuance of notice based on subjective satisfaction of Municipality re existence of nuisance; if no reply or consent, Municipality passes order under sub-s.(2). But if objection or consent subject to modification under sub-s.(3), Special Officer enquires into entire matter including existence of nuisance when absolute objection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Objection to notice includes denial of nuisance existence; Special Officer must enquire into fact of nuisance, not just manner of discharge; scheme protects against capricious exercise.

court_reasoning.text: Special Officer erred in holding enquiry beyond scope re nuisance existence; denied himself jurisdiction; order set aside; constitutional issue not decided.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry to be completed without undue delay as notice from 1956.

holdings.text: When absolute objection to notice under s.153A(1), Special Officer under s.153A(3) must enquire into existence of nuisance and manner of discharge.
Special Officer's order dated 16 July 1958 set aside; remit for enquiry into whether nuisance exists.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 (as applied to Saurashtra)
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates discharge of effluent; scheme for notice, Special Officer enquiry into nuisance and manner when objected.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenge to ss.153A-153G violating fundamental rights; Art.19 challenge not decided.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings before Special Officer deemed judicial proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Special Officer has powers of Civil Court in specified matters.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed with costs; Special Officer's order set aside for failing to enquire into existence of nuisance; matter remitted for full enquiry without delay; Art.32 petition rendered infructuous.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside order of Special Officer dated 16 July 1958; remit for enquiry into nuisance existence and proceed expeditiously.

key_quotes.text: the Special Officer apparently made no attempt to construe the provisions of sub-s. 3 of s.153A of the Act. In our opinion, he erred in holding that it was beyond the scope of his enquiry to enquire into the question whether, in fact, the nuisance alleged by the Municipality existed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on error by Special Officer regarding scope of enquiry.

key_quotes.text: Sub-s. 3 was a protection to the party objecting to the requisition.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legislative intent behind Special Officer appointment.

key_quotes.text: Proceedings of this kind ought to be handled with the utmost expedition because if a nuisance exists it should be removed without delay in order to preserve the health of the community and the fertility of the soil.
key_quotes.speaker: court
